title: Boost for Boris Johnson as Investors Back British leader to Win Next General Election after Brexit Setback
text:
Text size

A group of heavyweight investors that manage hundreds of billions of pounds have backed Prime Minister Boris Johnson to win a snap general election and keep the Conservative Party in power, as events in parliament on Saturday brought the prospect of an early ballot closer.

According to an anonymous poll of 49 influential investors, conducted before the weekend, almost 30% believe the British public will vote to keep the Tories in government. Political betting markets predict an election by Christmas.

Johnson formally asked the European Union on Saturday night to delay the country’s departure from the bloc for the third time after the British parliament postponed a decision on whether to back his divorce deal.

Johnson was forced to send a letter to the EU to request a delay to Brexit—but did so without including his signature. The request was accompanied by a second letter, signed by Johnson, saying he believes a delay would be a mistake.

The PM was required by law to ask the EU for an extension to the 31 October deadline after losing a vote in the Commons on October 19—the first Saturday session since the 1982 Falklands War.

The political turmoil has brought forward the likelihood of a snap U.K. election.

The poll of investors, conducted by opinion sharing platform Procensus, found that a further 26% believe the Tories would be able to form a majority government with the help of Nigel Farage’s Brexit Party. Not one investor, however, said the left-wing Labour Party would be able to come to power on its own. The rest predicted either a Liberal Democrat or Labour-led coalition.

Helena Morrissey, the City fund manager who is in the running to replace Mark Carney as governor of the Bank of England, said: “The most important thing at this juncture—and a point on which everyone I speak to agrees—is that we move forward as a country. Personally, I am confident the Tories can lead, with a decent majority.”

Sir Martin Sorrell, the advertising veteran, told FN: “I think [the Tories] can win. The cabinet is a good one. The prime minister also has a strong post-Brexit vision.”

European Council President Donald Tusk said on Twitter on Saturday that the extension request had arrived and he would begin consulting with EU leaders, who will respond in the coming days.

In his letter to Tusk, Johnson wrote: “I regret causing my fellow leaders to devote more time and energy to a question I had hoped we had resolved last week.”

David Buik, a City commentator, said of the Procensus poll: “Yes, I think the Tories are the only party that could command a majority in the House of Commons, with a leader who is regarded as positive.

“Regardless of political persuasion I think the electorate is of the opinion that the prospect of a Corbyn government is far more daunting than Brexit—deal or no deal—and will vote accordingly.”

In his letter to Tusk, Johnson said the government will press on with efforts to pass the revised Brexit deal agreed with EU leaders last week into law, and that he is confident of doing so by October 31.
